plausible_answers.text: Aid in the Selection of Acu-points

qas.question: What did Androsthenes use the noon and midnight manual for?

context: The earliest recorded account of a <b5_0>circadian process<b5_0/> dates from the <a0_0>4th century B.C.E<a0_0/>., when <a1_0>Androsthenes<a1_0/>, a ship captain serving under Alexander the Great, described <b6_0>diurnal leaf<b6_0/> movements of the <a2_0>tamarind<a2_0/> tree. The observation of a circadian or <b8_0>diurnal process in humans<b8_0/> is mentioned in <b7_0>Chinese<b7_0/> <a3_0>medical<a3_0/> texts dated to around the <a4_0>13th century<a4_0/>, including the Noon and Midnight Manual and the Mnemonic Rhyme to <b9_0>Aid in the Selection of Acu-points<b9_0/> According to the Diurnal Cycle, the Day of the Month and the Season of the Year.
